div.p: 1. VI. Sunday

Heard Professor Willard this morning from Romans 10. [“]But the righteousness which is of Faith speaketh on this wise. Say not in thine heart, Who shall ascend into Heaven? (that is to bring Christ down from above:) 7. Or who shall descend into the deep? (that is to bring up Christ again from the dead) 8: But what saith it? The word is nigh thee, even in thy mouth, and in thy heart: that is the word of faith, which we preach.” It was a Sermon upon the right of private judgment in religious concerns and the interpretation of the Scriptures— Rational and cogent. The afternoon text was from Psalm [“]They shall bear fruit in their Old Age.” Mr Willard and his Son dined with us, and also my brother— After the afternoon Service I read two Sermons of Swift—one upon the Martyrdom of Charles the first, preached on Sunday the 30th of January 1725. 26. and the other upon the excellence of Christianity in opposition to the Heathen Philosophy. The political Sermon is in the rankest tone of Toryism—repeatedly styling Charles the blessed Martyr, and raving at the wicked puritans— He nevertheless declares his approbation of the expulsion of James the second—passes a short and cold encomium upon William the third, and pronounces the judges who decided the right of Charles I to levy ship-money wicked. He considers the dissenters of his own times as the successors of the Puritans, and has a fling at them for not observing the day as a religious solemnity— It would be an amusing Speculation to compare this Sermon with that of Dr Mayhew upon the same Catastrophe. But I have never heard or read a political Sermon, consistent with the Spirit of Christianity. The Sermon upon the superior Excellence of the Christian Religion to the Grecian Philosophy, is a good subject very badly treated— Shallow, superficial and unjust to the philosophers. He probably knew nothing of the Grecian Philosophy—and speaks from ignorance. It is a poor tribute of praise to the Christian system of morals to declare it superior to that which is itself weak and absurd— Its real merit consists in its superiority to the sublimest and profoundest conceptions of the human mind— I also this Evening finished reading Condorcet’s Life of Voltaire— It is almost unqualified Panegyric— Much less entertaining than I had expected, uniformly grave and didactic, with scarcely a sprightly thought in the book. The best part of it is the Summary of his hero’s character with which he closes.
2. IV:15. Monday.

Mr Whitney brought me this morning a Letter from President Quincy enclosing a printed copy of the Constitution of the Phillips Academy at Andover. From this and the Rules and Regulations of the Derby School at Hingham it will be for me to draw up the plan of the Classical School to be established here, and it is perhaps just that this duty should devolve upon me. The Masons are yet at work upon my Chimney, and Josiah Adams junr. came about the additional bookshelves which I must fit up in my Northeastern upper chamber to stow away a large portion of my library— These works must be precipitated to enable me to go towards the close of this month to Washington— Harvey Field came to give me notice that on Saturday Night, my house at the foot of Penn’s Hill; the house in which I was born had
taken fire, and suffered, very considerable injury— The fire by the blessing of God was extinguished so that the house was saved— The fire happened in the same way as it did in 1803 to my house in Hanover Street— It was now in the part of the House occupied by William Field; and Harvey asked who was to be at the expense of the repairs— I said it must be he who made the fire; but he said William Field had been told that the repairs must be made by me— For the damage had been occasioned, by placing a Fireframe in the Chimney, for which W. Field had received permission from my brother— I said my brother had not given him permission to set the house on fire— He asked me to come and look at it, which I promised to do to-morrow. He said that he and William Field were both going this day to Brighton. The Northeasterly Storm, continues; but now without the gale— Towards the dusk of Evening I walked to Mr Sever the Schoolmaster’s who is also the Town-Clerk— I asked to see the Record upon the Town Book of the last boundary line between the Towns of Quincy and Milton— He lent me the Report made by the Select men themselves—Daniel Spear and John Souther on the part of Quincy in November 1826. which I brought home and had copied— I unpacked a few more of my books, and proceeded in the abstract of my father’s title vouchers. W. Greenleaf is copying his early Journals. I read only a few pages of the Appendix to Condorcet’s life of Voltaire.
3. V:45. Tuesday.

Much of the day was again absorbed in continuing the abstract from my father’s title Deeds, and yet they were not completed— Mr Humphreys the Surveyor called this Morning; and gave me a minute of the contents of the three Lots of Woodland surveyed last week by him for the Estate of my father. Their amount fully makes up the quantity of land to which he was entitled, by all the voucher deeds he has left. I spoke to him of the course of the boundary line between the Towns of Milton and Quincy; as likely to illustrate that of the several Lots in the Deeds of 600 Acres lands— He was hurried to proceed to Dedham, and could not wait for further elucidations. There was rain all the morning; Some additional boxes of my books were unpacked; but I could not find room for them upon my shelves. My brother called here after dinner, with the papers relating to Lands of mine sold in the State of Vermont, and to an undivided remnant of the Estate of Norton Quincy— I had promised Harvey Field, to go and look at the breach in the house at the foot of Penn’s Hill made by the fire on Saturday Night. My brother took me there in his Chaise— The floor has burnt through from the cellar, and two large beams are entirely burnt off. The damage to the house is considerable; but the house has been spared— In that house, I was born. It cannot last many years longer; yet I cannot suppress a hope that it will outlast me.— Had it been consumed I should have felt it as a calamity far beyond its intrinsic value— My own death is an event which cannot be remote— To part with the world and with life is the Law to which I must soon submit; but there is a lingering attachment to this Earth—which looks beyond the grave and fondly hopes that Children and Grand-children to be followed by later Generations will enjoy life where I have enjoyed, when this generation and the next will all be in the tomb— May this weakness be forgiven me and this mentis gratissimus error go with me to the close of life.
I walked home, and spent the Evening in reading the appendix to Condorcet’s Life of Voltaire and a number of Voltaire’s Letters— There are two between him and J. J. Rousseau upon Rousseau’s sending him his Discourse upon the Inequalities of Condition among men, which deserve to be studied as models. There are also two remarkable subsequent Letters in one of which Voltaire asks Rousseau, permission to publish Voltaire’s own Letter, while Rousseau’s answer tells him that the request relieves him from much concern which he had felt at a prospect that the Letters were becoming public, in consequence of his having lent them to two or three persons to read— There is in Voltaire’s Letters an unaccountable fascination.
4. IV:45. Wednesday.

The masons who have reduced my kitchen chimney, and are putting up in it a Rumford Roaster, Boilers, Kettle and Steamer, recommended to me the addition of a Smoak Jack in the Chimney; to which I assented; whereupon, one of them went into Boston, and brought out Mr Wall, who makes them— This is an invention with which I was not acquainted and which I now adopt by way of experiment. I had commenced last Evening a Letter to judge Story, which sundry interruptions this day prevented me from finishing till this Evening; and which thus occupied the day. The Subjects upon which I commenced this Correspondence are copious, and in compressing my ideas, I fear I shall not be altogether intelligible to the Judge— My purpose was to put him upon thinking of some things of high moment which it was obvious he had not duly meditated—to check his strain of unbounded, and unfounded panegyrick upon the bitterest enemies of his Country that ever lived, and to hint to him the incongruity of recommending the Study of Philosophy, with a sneer upon Plato. May the result of it turn to good: Mr Lemuel Bracket came to invite me to attend a survey of his Wood lot, bordering upon mine on Pine hill to which I agreed— I told him that Asa French had informed me of his having seen the plan of the old Braintree Common Lands in the possession of his brother James Brackett— He said he would make enquiry for it of his brother who was now here— My brother dined with us. We examined the papers relating to the Vermont Lands, and to the undivided remnant of Norton Quincy’s Estate in Braintree— I agreed to sign the power of Attorney to him to act in this case in behalf of the representatives of my Mother’s interest in the claim. He shewed me also the papers relating to the division of the Medford Estate with Mr Felt. Miss Thaxter came from Hingham to spend a few days with us. Deacon Adams and Mr Daniel Greenleaf were here; and are to finish this Evening the appraisement of the remaining lots yet unsold of my father’s Estate— The Deacon renewed to me his proposals for an exchange of Lands, to which I do not much incline— Thomas Adams junr. brought me his share of the Quincy Canal, which I purchased of him without the Note— I had that indeed already from Brigham; to whom he had sold it. I had time this Evening to read only two or three Letters of the Appendix to the life of Voltaire.
5. V. Thursday.

The principal purpose of a Diary as mine has been kept is to perform the Pythagorean precept, and render to myself an account of the manner in which I spend every moment of my time. Yet it often happens that when the day is gone I am myself at a loss to remember how it slip’d away— And so it was with this— I continued unpacking and putting up books; and Mr Clap the Mason from Boston, finished his work in my kitchen with the exception of the Smoke-jack still to be put up. Towards Evening I walked out— called at Mr Sever’s and left the copy which he had left me of the line last drawn between the Towns of Quincy and Milton— Mr Sever was not returned from School. I stop’d next at Mr Brigham’s to leave the certificate of the Canal Share 12.49—to be made out in my name, but he was gone to Boston. I went to my brothers, and passed a couple of hours there. His wife returned from Boston, and brought me a note from Charles with a copy of the Life of Arthur Lee, and a packet for Mary Foster— After returning home I finished a Letter to the Trustees of the Boston Athenaeum in reply to a Report of a Committee of that body, concerning my interest in that Institution— Read two or three Letters of the appendix to the Life of Voltaire. I received this day Letters from my wife; from Mr Jared Sparks—from Mr John Bailey with a copy of Mr Jefferson’s scorings upon the first and third Volumes of my father’s Defence of the American Constitutions, and from C. M. Putnam of Marietta Ohio, with his Dissertation upon the character of Thomas Shepard, delivered at the Andover Exhibition.
6. IV:30. Friday.

Part of this day was consumed in a fruitless search for papers. Deacon Spear sold the wood lots, on my Lawyer’s Common— The manner of making these Sales is by staking out small Lots of ground, and selling them upon the spot, at Auction— The wood to be cut down, and taken away by the purchasers. I walked up to the place; and went entirely round the lot before I found them. There were about thirty persons there; men chiefly residing in the neighbourhood. Labouring men, who purchased chiefly for their own consumption. The management of wood land is one of the things upon which I want information. A part of the Science of husbandry, upon which these my neighbours now amuse themselves at the expence of my ignorance, and take advantage of it. Deacon Adams and his brother renewed their Siege upon me to swap land with them— They wish me to take land that is good for nothing, in exchange for land which is good; and from the facility of my nature there is a prospect that they will succeed— Harvey Field chaffered with me about the site of the School house which they have built upon my land; and for which I told him I should claim ground Rent— He asked me what I would take for it— I said the land was worth a thousand dollars an Acre— I’ll give it said he— So the land is mine.— Not so fast said I— Take a whole Acre, and you shall have it— Josiah Nightingale had purchased one of the lots of Wood, which by the conditions of the Sale is to be cut down carried away and paid for before the first of April next. Nightingale came to me, and said—I suppose you will allow me another winter to take off part of it— I told him he must take all the Conditions of Sale from Deacon Spear— These men
are too sharp for me to deal with, and some of them understand the art of Flattery better than Courtiers— It was half past two when I got home; and I was too weary for reading or writing the remainder of the day— Harvey Field offered me, as we were returning six dollars for an old Oak tree near his house under which I used to pick acorns when I was a child— I told him the sight of it was worth more to me than six dollars— I spent the afternoon in idleness, and the Evening in talking with Miss Thaxter about King Josiah, Hilkiah the High Priest and Huldah the prophetess, and in reading certain passages of the Old and New Testament. W. Greenleaf, and Mary Foster passed the Evening abroad.
7. IV:45. Saturday.

I intended to have gone into Boston this Morning; but there came on a North-East Storm with heavy rain which continued the whole day and confined me to the house. I received Letters from my wife, and from Charles, enclosing one from Sidney Brooks. I wrote to Mr Brooks and to my wife which occupied the day, excepting the time consumed in a search of papers relating to the Execution of my father’s Will. Upon this search I found several things to be done, which had escaped from my mind: of every object which requires a continuance of action at distant intervals of time, there should be periodical Seasons for taking up and reviewing what has already been done— I am preparing a fifth Account for Settlement at the probate Office: and meet a question whether the fourth has been settled— I took it to Dedham for that purpose on the 2d. of October 1827. but the judge was gone upon a Journey, and no probate Court was then held. Whether it was afterwards settled or not my Memory does not decisively Report. Interests of high importance to myself and others require that I should proceed in this affair with great regularity, and putting every thing upon record. The Account that I had drawn up and prepared last Summer must be made up anew and the cancelling of the Mortgages, be entered upon my own book of Record of the Administration— I finished reading this Evening the Appendix to Condorcet’s Life of Voltaire; and began the memoirs of his own Life written by Voltaire himself—a posthumous work, which I read at its first publication in 1784. At the age of 22—Voltaire was imprisoned in the Bastille, for a short poem called Les J’ai Vus—or Things I have seen— Condorcet somewhat equivocally disavows the authorship; but gives the Poem itself in the Appendix— It is every way worthy of Voltaire, and was very naturally in the eyes of the Regent worthy of the Bastille. His Declaration or Petition to the King of Prussia, upon his arrest and imprisonment at Francfort for the Livre de Poeshies du Roi mon Maitre is ludicrous, by the mixture of excessive terror, of affected profound respect, and of involuntary irrepressible sarcasm of which it is composed— He begins by declaring that he is dying and keeps through the whole paper that he has but a few days to live— Tis the last Scene of the Fourberies de Scapin over again to a tittle.
8. VI. Sunday.

Heard Mr Flagg of Roxbury this Morning from Joshua 24.15. [“]But as for me and my house, we will serve the Lord[”]—and in the afternoon from Luke 12.35. “Let your loins be girded about, and your lights burning; 36. And ye yourselves like unto men that wait for their Lord, when he will return from the wedding; that when he cometh and knocketh, they may open to him immediately.” This was a discourse upon the duty of being prepared for death, and as frequently happens, the text was more deeply impressive upon me than the Sermon. I think much upon the subject, and yet have not set my household in order. I have much to do to prepare for my departure, and have frequent admonitions in the state of my health to do it without further delay— Eight months of Leisure have passed away and how little have I done. Worldly concerns still absorb my time— How hard it is to break away from them— Mr Flagg who is settled in the Parish at Roxbury of which Mr Bradford was formerly the Pastor, dined with us—and my brother’s Son Isaac Hull— I read a Sermon of Swift, upon the duty of doing good; but which is a mere invective against Wood’s half-pence. Read also two Sermons of Barrow upon Slander— They are for the substance, admirable discourses—full of excellent observation, and sound principle; but altogether obsolete in Style. Lord Chatham is said to have been a great admirer of Barrow, and so was my father— But this writer, as well as Tillotson and Butler is like a Chesnut surrounded by such a rough and prickly Coat, that you must carefully cast off the shell before you can come at the nutritive part— His text is [“]He that uttereth Slander is a Fool[”]— The first Sermon describes the various modes of Slander, and the second the proofs of its folly. There are a number of singular and obsolete words—curt for short—shrewd for shrowd and parlous for dangerous, in which sense it is used by hostess Quickly in Shakspeare; I had always supposed, as one of her samples of vulgar bad English— My brother was here part of the Evening; and then went to Mr Beale’s Sunday Evening Concert— My Ladies also went; but I was occupied and unwell, with stitches of Rhumatism, and kept my chamber. I spoke to my brother of my desire to establish the classical School in this Town, and also of my wish that his Son John Quincy should be sent to a School, of preparation for the University; to which he assented.
9. V. Monday.

I rode into Boston this morning with John Thomas. Stopp’d at Mr Withington’s and left his plan of his last Survey, that he might make a correction of a mistake— And I asked for his Bill— I took to Boston the Volumes of my books mutilated at the Athenaeum; and left them at my Son Charles’s to be sent to the Trustees— I took likewise eight Volumes of my father’s Letter Books of the Revolutionary Period, which I left in Charles’s Study to be there used by Mr Sparks during the ensuing Winter, for the confection of his compilations; but with express injunctions to Charles not to let them be taken out of his house. His wife was not at home and I went to his Office, where I sent for Mr. Nathl. Curtis, and shewed him the duplicate of my last Letter to Petty Vaughan, and told him that if I should receive the authority which I had demanded from Mr Vaughan, to draw the balance of Thomas Boylston’s property from his hands, I should incline to authorise some perfectly safe house; as of
the Barings’, before I should hazard the drawing of Bills which might be returned protested: this he approved— I procured sundry small Articles for drawing: a pair of compasses and scale of equal parts— I lost my time for going to the Registry of Deeds, and returned to Charles’s House, where I met Mr Alexander H. Everett recently returned from Europe. I gave Charles’s wife the Letter from mine containing the orders which she sends for sundry small Articles, to be taken on by me— Returned to Quincy to dine— Stop’d again at Mr Withington’s and he gave me the plan with the error of date corrected; and his bill receipted which I had not however time to pay. I came back over Neponset Bridge, reached home at half past 3. and found my family at dinner— We spent the Evening at Mr Marston’s, after I had read a few Letters of the Correspondence between Voltaire and Madame du Deffand. I was surprized to read among Voltaire’s, one written some years after his Commentary upon Corneille was published, and in which he speaks of that Poet with profound contempt. Says that he wrote his Commentary upon him, to provide a Marriage portion for Mademoiselle Corneille, and that he thanks God he never read ten or twelve of Corneille’s Plays upon which he did not comment. One or two of his Letters are dismally gloomy—
10. V. Tuesday.

I had an indifferent Night; being more than once, awaked by twinges of rhumatism, or stitches of some more threatening disease which within the last four months has returned upon me several Times— They are of a pressure and severity to warn me that my departure may be sudden and Solitary; I find as yet relief by an instantaneous change of position; but this may be not always my lot— Cold and damp weather thus affects me now, habitually, and although I resorted yesterday to the last of my flannels, the waistcoat it proves not a sufficient shelter. May the admonition not be lost upon me. I began the draft of a Deed, in my Sketch diurnal. Deacon Spear called upon me and settled with me, for his Sales of standing wood on my Lawyers common. They amounted to 302 dollars of which he takes ten per Cent for selling and collecting the proceeds of Sales, one per Cent for the State tax on Auctions— He paid me 73 dollars in cash, and gave me his Note, payable the 1st. of May next for $195:80. the remainder. Mr. Curtis came before Deacon Spear had left me— I went with him to the probate Court, where I filed the fifth Account of the Executors of John Adams, and the Supplementary inventory, returned by the Appraisers, and to which I was sworn— Judge Robbins thought he had no Authority to indicate the particular ten Acres of woodland in the 600 Acres, which should be set off to me, for the Lot, conveyed to me by my father by his Deed of Septr. 1819. but that it must be done, by Petition to the Court of Common Pleas of the County— There was in the Account a charge of allowance to the Executors left in blank, and upon which the judge after asking some questions took time for advisement— Mr Flint of Cohasset was there with a Woman, who was taking out Letters of Administration upon the Estate of her deceased husband— I called at Mr Brigham’s with the Certificate of Canal Share N. 49. to be transferred and upon making enquiries find that the prospects of the Canal have much declined since
the early part of the Summer when I came home— The Stone cutting business upon which the success of the Canal depended is departing from the Town itself and even the workmen who were occupied upon it here, are transferring the Scene of their operations to Sandy Bay— I went to my brother’s and delivered to him a Letter from his Son Thomas, written at Charleston S.C. where he arrived on the 30th of last Month— The North-east Storm shortened his passage— I found my brother and his family at dinner— Mr Curtis dined with me, and I gave him some advice for Mrs Boylston with regard to her two Grand sons my wards now at the Academy of Leicester. The day was thus absorbed.
11. V. Wednesday.

The greatest part of this day was engaged in unpacking and putting up books, the room for which is yet exceedingly scanty. Much of my time is absorbed by looking in to many of the books before they are put up, and the day is gone before I am aware of it. Josiah Adams junr. was here, and made three additional shelves over the doors of my bed chamber. Miss Thaxter’s brother called here this afternoon upon his return from Boston to Hingham, and Mr Price Greenleaf was here in the Evening— Alpheus Spear came with a load of Wood, and I had conversation with him upon the renewal of his lease— I told him I would renew the lease to him and his brother for two three or five years at their option at the rent they now pay which is 600 dollars a year, and which I was determined not to reduce any further— It has already been reduced from 1000 dollars to 600— He urged very hard for a reduction to 500 which I positively declined— He then said he would bring his brother to talk with me to which I readily agreed, but told him it would make no alteration in my determination— I lost the day for all writing except the Journal of yesterday, and the draft of the Deed which I propose to give of the two pews the Monument and Tomb; the recital in which will apparently be longer than the Deed— In the Evening I read a few Letters of the Correspondence of Voltaire with the Marquise du Deffand. This correspondence proves that he disbelieved any future State of existence, and that he was all his lifetime flattering himself that he should have the glory of demolishing the Christian Religion. His life appears to have been a long disease, and he was always imagining or representing himself to his Correspondents as at the point of Death. He constantly complains that all his Letters sent by the Post-Office are opened; he published his irreligious books under fictitious names, and was continually disavowing that he was the author of them— There is a very good Letter from the President Henault to him censuring his Philosophie de l’Histoire by the pretended Abbe Bazin; which was not even a fictitious name— There was such a person, who wrote to Voltaire complaining of the misuse of his name and to whom Voltaire replied only by fool’s jokes.
12. IV:15. Thursday.

I sent yesterday to Mr Hubbard, the Sexton of the Meeting House, and requested him to be ready at as short a notice as possible to go in to Boston, upon the arrival of the vessel, which I am expecting from New-York. This morning I sent to George Vesey and desired him to go and look at the house at the foot of Penn’s hill, and report to me what would be the cost of
repairing the damage done by the late fire— I went into Boston this morning with my brother. Stop’d at Mr Withington’s in Dorchester and paid him his Bill for his last Surveys— The weather was pinching cold— I took to Boston thirteen Volumes of my father’s Letter Books, which I deposited in the Library chamber at Charles’s house— They are to be open for inspection to Mr Sparks, who is to take copies of such of them as he may want for his publication— But I took a receipt of the Books from Charles, with a promise that none of them shall be taken out of his house. I called at his Office, and then at the Registry of Deeds where I took the copies I had ordered of the Braintree Common Lands Deeds— Procured some drawing paper, on which I propose to have the plans of my lands reduced— Paid a visit to Mr Alexander H. Everett at the Tremont House. Received a Letter from Coll. Josiah Quincy junr. Secretary to the Trustees of the Boston Athenaeum, with a vote restoring to me my right to a Proprietor’s Share, and a Certificate of Share N. 255. Dined with my brother, and my Son Charles, at Lieutt. Governor T. L. Winthrop’s. P. C. Brooks 2. Everetts T. Welsh— Jos. Coolidge— G. Brimmer— B. Gorham and Mr Frothingham were there. Literary Conversation with E. Everett, and Genl. Dearborn— Came home with my brother in the Evening. A chilly ride. Found Mr George W. Beale with the Ladies.
13. IV:45. Friday.

Mr George Vesey came this morning and informed me, what he thought was the extent of the damage done by the fire, to the house at the foot of Penn’s hill, which I directed him to repair— I went to Boston and dined with Mr Edward Brooks. I suffered so much from the cold weather, that on coming to Boston Neck, I left the Chaise, and walked into the City. Called at Cary and Dickinson’s Shop but neither of them was there. At Mr James H. Foster’s, I saw his daughters Elizabeth and Louisa. At Judge Davis’s I made some enquiries respecting the preface to the third Volume of Hutchinson’s History, which the judge could not satisfactorily answer— There was much negotiation to obtain the publication of it at all. The Editor is a Grandson of Governor Hutchinson— He would not publish it in this Country; nor in England without a contribution to defray the expense of the publication. The editor sent me one copy of it with a civil Letter of acknowledgment for my contribution, and in that copy there was an interesting preface containing some account of the last days of Governor Hutchinson, after he took refuge in England. For my contribution three copies of the volume have been delivered to me here; without the preface. I asked the judge how it happened that the preface had been withdrawn from these Volumes he said the Editor had written that it was not applicable to this Country: but that he had sent him and Mr Savage, each a copy of the book with the preface— The judge asked me, if I would Review it for the North American Review— Edward Everett had asked me the same question yesterday— I said I would if Mr Sparks would publish the Review as I should write it; but not if it was to be written so as to give no offence to any one— The judge spoke to me also of the recent publication of the Memoir of Arthur Lee; and the Correspondence connected with it; particularly as it bears upon the character of Dr Franklin. He mentioned
also the deficiency of payment of one years annuity of Mr W. N. Boylston’s donations to the College—which he said he had paid. I called at the Registry of Deeds and examined the Deed of Elisha Cook and others to Samuel Shrimpton and others of 8 Jany: 1698. of the waste Lands in Braintree, which still recurs to other Documents in the Records of the Town of Boston— I could not find the Office of the City Clerk. Charles was gone to Weston— The company at Mr Edward Brooks’s was chiefly of the Brooks family. Alexander and Edward Everett— Mr Sparks and Mr Greenwood— After dinner I stop’d about half an hour at Charles’s—he had not returned from Weston; and I got home between 8 and 9 in the Evening— Miss Thaxter had returned in the afternoon Stage to Hingham.
14. V. Saturday.

On rising this morning I found the ground covered with Snow. As the weather moderated it turned to rain and before night the ground was bare— It confined me however to the house and for my daily task of exercise, I was compelled to unpack and put up my books— I have nearly got through with my boxes, and must find room for stowing away all the books brought out from Boston— This is I hope and pray the last removal they are destined to undergo during my life, and I cannot flatter myself that I shall ever possess them so as to derive from them all the benefit which I had hoped— It remains for me to submit with cheerfulness to a different dispensation and to rely that in another age and under other auspices my intentions may be no longer barren or unfruitful— The cold weather of this Season precludes me also from the possibility of writing before breakfast: and so I betook myself this morning to reading. I began with the first chapter, of the seventh Book of James Grahame’s history of the rise and progress of the United States of America It is the foundation of the Colony of Pennsylvania and the Life of William Penn— This is the first Historian who has done Justice to the founders of the North-American Colonies. It has heretofore happened that the first Settlers of New-England have suffered in reputation even from their own historians— Hume and Robertson have slandered them systematically. On the other hand Penn has had more than Justice done him— Grahame meets it out to him with an equal balance— Penn’s Toleration, and the Quaker disclaimer of carnal weapons, were excellent ingredients for the Settlement of a Colony—but his proprietary Government was a monarchy— His controversy with Lord Baltimore is not creditable to his disinterestedness, and his political system terminated in a principality devolved upon his descendants—and dissolved only by the Revolutionary War of Independence— Neither Penn nor his Institutions were Republican— In the Evening I read a few pages of the second Book, which commences the History of New-England.
15. IV:45 Sunday.

Heard Mr Peter Whitney, in the morning from 1. John 3.7. “Little children, let no man deceive you; he that doeth righteousness is righteous, even as he is righteous” and in the afternoon, upon the things hard to be understood in the Epistle to the Romans Chapter 8–16— This Series of Sermons has become so tiresome, that many of Mr Whitney’s parishioners wish it were finished— He leaves all the
difficulties where he finds them; and approaches none of the most insuperable. Richard C. Greenleaf, and my brother’s Son Joseph dined with us: and General Sumner with his wife’s little Son Perry, were here at tea—The cold cramps my fingers so that I can scarcely write at all— I read a Sermon which Mr Bigelow has recently published, entitled Paul at Athens, a Preacher of Unitarianism, of which he has sent me a copy, ingenious and forcible—perhaps not altogether candid— I read also two Sermons of Barrow—one upon detraction— The other against rash and censorious judgments— They seem to be sequels to the two Sermons upon Slander. I hardly know what to think of this writer— His reputation stands high, and there is a Story that Lord Chatham passed some extravagant commendation upon him. My father had a high opinion of him, and his Sermons are yet so fashionable that a new Edition of them has been recently published— I find him dry and somewhat tedious— There is nothing in them that I should call eloquence— He proves his maxims of morals as he would prove a theorem of Euclid— There is nothing in these discourses for the heart. Obsolete words and a crabbed Style, much thought; sound sense—frequent quotations, Latin and Greek, from authors now forgotten, and often in sentences not worthy of preservation— I finished reading the Chapter of Grahame’s History containing the account of the first Settlement of New-England. It is excellent, and for the first time renders ample Justice to our Puritan fore-fathers. He has detected and gently rebuked the misrepresentations of Hume, Robertson and Chalmers— His exposures of them rouse my indignation— Never were men more scandalously traduced than have been the first Settlers of New-England— Mr Sparks told me that Grahame’s History had little success in England. This will of course affect its popularity here.
16. IV:30. Monday.

I finished at length this day the unpacking of my books, and got them housed. They are in lamentable confusion, and it is very doubtful whether I shall ever have the Time and means to put them in order. Mr Whitney called here with a card given him by a Mr Baker, of the New-England Stereotype Foundery at Boston, and proposing to print for me upon reasonable terms any work that I may have the intention of publishing. I told him I had none for the present; and that if I should have hereafter, I shall probably apply to the company for a further exposition of their Terms— Mr Cary came with his Bill for the erection of the Monument to the Memory of my father and mother in the Stone Temple at Quincy; which I paid. He spoke of putting up behind the bust a black marble obelisk about four feet high; to bring the bust more in relief; but I have concluded to defer doing any thing further for the present. It is probable the walls of the House will be painted, and another loose marble to be adjusted to their Wall, would lay a foundation for a necessity of future repairs. My brother was here this forenoon and also General Sumner, who had been to see the Monument and approved it— He told me that S. L. Knapp had written a biographical account of his father, which he thought admirable, and also a monumental inscription upon his Tomb in the Park place burying ground at Boston. The
General spoke to me also of certain speculations which had been proposed to him in New-York in Lands in the Mexican State of Texas— He says that all the Lands in the State have been granted with the assent of the Mexican Congress to purchasers Citizens of the United States, who are now offering them for Sale at New-York— And that it is expected the present Administration of the United States will purchase the State of Texas of the Mexican Republic. I told him I did not believe the Mexican Republic would or could sell the State; but I thought our present Administration would take it by War; and if so I believed the result of it would be to break up our Union— Mr Beale and Mr Miller came to speak of the distribution of the Lot of Land near the Meeting House, given by my father to the Town. Mr Thomas Greenleaf afterwards came and conversed with me on the same Subject. They have sent for Mr Fuller, a Surveyor at Boston, who is to come and view the ground next Wednesday Morning and make a plan for laying out the ground; and they invited me to be present at the time when he will be there— With my little family I spent the Evening at Daniel Greenleaf’s, and the first time for several years I joined in a hand at whist— Read the second Chapter of the second Book of Grahame’s History with great Satisfaction— The Style of this writer though plain is elegant. He writes apparently under deep religious impressions without enthusiasm; a lofty sense of morals—tolerant, humane, devoted to Justice and impartiality; with a philosophical Spirit, and a fervent love of Liberty, and a burning zeal, for the prevalence of human rights. This is precisely the character required, to write the History of the Settlement of New-England; as well as that of the North American Union— There is bitterness against the Princes of the house of Stuart; and they were doubtless all bad characters— There is a leaning favourable to almost all eminent Puritans—even to Sir Henry Vane, Hugh Peters and Cromwell. Yet he spares them not when he thinks their characters deserve censure— The narrative is concise, and clear; and he gives to the religious dissensions which raged so early in the Colony an interest of which they scarcely seemed susceptible— He seems to me to underrate Winthrop’s Journal, but he very justly charges Savage with underrating Mather’s Magnalia.
17. IV:30. Tuesday.

Warm rain the whole day—confined me to the house; put up the last of my books, upon the shelves— They are in great disorder—many odd volumes of large Collections are missing— I have yet to assort them; and to make out a catalogue of them; for which Time and Perseverance are essential— Mr Humphrey brought me this morning my plans, and his Bills— The Plans all correspond with sufficient exactness with my Deeds and previous plans, excepting the Penn’s Valley farm, where there is a deficiency of more than 20 Acres. Mr Humphrey said Mr Lemuel Brackett had engaged him to go over the ground and mark the lines between his lot and mine upon Pine Hill— I agreed to go with them for that purpose on Friday or Saturday next, if the weather should be fair— Mr Humphrey promised to go round that part of the Penn’s Valley farm where the mistake may be at the same time; and said if there was a mistake he would notify it without additional charge— Isaac Bass was here respecting an exchange of Land between him and me, which may suit the convenience of us both— I had spoken of it last Summer to his brother’s, but had cooled upon the project since I abandoned that of building, upon the Hill. We examined the bearing of the ground upon a plan reduced from that of Withington, and agreed to think more about it before coming to a determination— Bass said he would prefer to exchange rather than to sell, and I told him I had no desire whatever to purchase—
Finished the draft of a Deed of the Tomb and Monument of my father and mother, and of the Pews N. 1. and 2 in the Stone Temple to the Supervisors of the Adams Temple and School fund, which I have prepared for their examination, and if they please, acceptance. I read the third Chapter of the second Book of Grahame’s History of North-America— It fulfills every wish I have had with regard to the History of New-England—and redeems the characters of its founders from the Slanders of Robertson, Chalmers and Hutchinson. This Chapter contains the memorable incidents of the first New England federation—the Coinage of Money— The Labours of Elliot and Mayhew in behalf of the Indians— The Synod of the Churches— The Controversies of Massachusetts with the Long Parliament— Cromwell’s projects for transplanting the People to Ireland or Jamaica— The Persecutions of the Anabaptists and Quakers, the dangers of the Colonies, upon the Restoration of the Stuarts, and the Charters granted to Connecticut and Rhode-Island.
18. V. Wednesday.

Heavy rain almost the whole Night, which continued part of this morning. I went to French’s Tavern, where I had agreed to meet Mr T. Greenleaf. G. W. Beale and Edward Miller, with Mr Fuller the Surveyor from Boston; but neither of them was there. I then called at my brother’s and left a Letter from his Son Thomas to his Mother— I also gave him the draft of a Deed to the Supervisors of the Temple and School fund of the Tomb, monument and two Pews: and I had some conversation with my brother about sending his Son, John Quincy to School at Leicester. On returning home I found Elizabeth C. Adams and her Cousin Susan Harrod here; and they spent the day with us— The afternoon was consumed in commencing a Catalogue of my books; but before we had got through even a notice of the Folio Volumes, darkness came— I distress myself with the consciousness that my few hours of remaining life are slipping away from me unimproved— That my occupations are engrossed for transitory purposes, and that I am losing day after day without atchieving any thing— The Memoir of my father’s life has been six weeks suspended; and in the interval what have I done? I have made some small progress in preparation for my own departure, and that is all. I have brought my Books from Boston, and lodged them at this House. I have completed the Surveys of the Lands which belonged to my father’s Estate; and have nearly completed a Survey of all my own— I have plans of the whole—and in the event of my own decease very shortly; the labours of my Executors will be facilitated, though I have yet much to do to set my house in order. Another Summer of leisure and health if allowed me, will I trust be sufficient to enable me to leave my Affairs in some condition of regularity. May the Mercies of Providence not forsake me— I wrote short Letters to T. B. Adams junr. To Cuyler Staats who has sent me a copy of a Tribute of Panegyric upon De Witt Clinton, and to Charles M. Putnam returning him his Dissertation upon the character of Thomas Shepard. I read part of the Life of this eminent man in Mather’s Magnalia— The preface to the first Volume of Chalmers’s Political Annals— A Chapter of the life of Arthur Lee; and
the fourth Chapter of Grahame’s Second Book— It contains the account of Charles the second’s Royal Commissioners sent to New England—of Philip’s War—and of the Judgment of forfeiture against the first Charter of Massachusetts Bay.
19. III.45. Thursday.

A Mr Quinby brought me yesterday the first volume of a new work—an Encyclopaedia Americana, a Translation or imitation of a German work called Conversation’s Lexicon— Dr Lieber is one of the publishers of this work, of which there are to be twelve Volumes, one every quarter— I declined subscribing for it— This morning I rode to the Railway, and went upon the lot where Deacon Spear was selling some of my standing wood; but could not stay while he was making the Sale; I had met Mr Curtis and my two wards, who were coming out to visit me— I returned to them, after being half an hour upon the ground— They dined with us, and returned to Roxbury this Evening. I received a Letter from Sidney Brooks to Charles, which Mr Curtis undertook to deliver to him this Evening. Mr Curtis shewed me a draft of a form of deed to be given by the Executors of Ward N. Boylston, revised and abridged from Charles’s form; but which I thought was susceptible of further abridgement; which I accordingly proposed by erasure and interlineation, for the further inspection and revision of Mr C. P. Curtis and of Charles— There was a conveyance also to General Towne, of Mr Boylstone’s Mount Desert Credits and Lands; which required further revision— Mrs Boylston’s Accounts of Expenses for the two boys, during the year 1828. Mr Curtis took back to be receipted by her— I made many enquiries respecting the School at Leicester where the boys are placed; and examined Ward, the eldest in the 5th. book of the Aeneid, which I found he could construe, according to the manner in which they do construe at the Schools, the Classic Writers— Alpheus Spear came to talk with me again about his lease— He pleaded again for various indulgences, part of which I consented to and declined yielding the rest— He and his brother have concluded to renew the lease for five years; but each party reserving the power, to renounce it with a year’s notice in two years. He is to bring me their copy of the Lease, upon which I promised to endorse the renewal— I read this morning the fifth and last Chapter of the Second Book of Grahame’s History— Incomparably the best History of New-England from its settlement to the end of the 17th. century, that has ever been published— I have read it with great pleasure; and with no small mortification—pleasure to find Justice done at last to the pilgrim founders of this Empire. Mortification that this tardy Justice should be dispensed by a Stranger— Grahame is a profoundly religious man, and therefore indulges in no sarcasms at the piety of the pilgrims— He is a republican, and palliates none of the royal perfidies which they experienced— He has a tinge of that enthusiasm for which they were derided, and which was one of their virtues— He disbelieves not even witchcraft. He admires Sir Henry Vane, venerates Hugh Peters, and has a kindly feeling even for Oliver Cromwell. He says that Mather’s Magnalia is the most interesting performance that the Literature of New-England has ever produced, and that the biographical portions of it, are superior in dignity and interest to the compositions of Plutarch. I think this is overrating him— Yet Grahame freely censures his faults. He quotes from Dr Franklin with the highest Encomium another Work of Mather’s entitled Essays to do Good; which I have never seen, but still hope I shall see.
20. IV. Friday.

Conformably to my promise I called this morning at Mr Lemuel Bracketts where I met Mr Humphreys the Surveyor, and we went upon Pine Hill where we commenced the measurement from the corner boundary between Mr Brackett’s lot N. 4. and mine N. 3. we put up one or two heaps of Stones proceeding from East to West, when John Thomas came to say that Mr Fuller had come out from Boston, and the Supervisors wished me to be present at the Survey of the School House Lot. After some discourse with Mr Brackett, who wished me to purchase his lot, but asked 500 dollars for it, which I could not give, I left them to finish the drawing of the line and fixing of the bounds— Deacon Adams who had joined us went with me and W. C. Greenleaf, and we viewed the Penn’s Valley farm, as bounded on the plan of Mr Humphrey; but could perceive no mistake upon the plan, nor any thing which could account for the deficiency of more than twenty Acres of the Land, which there must be by comparison with the deeds— Deacon Adams promised to call upon me to-morrow, and look over my Deeds.— On returning I found Mr Fuller with Mr T. Greenleaf and G. W. Beale, in the road adjoining the School House lot; and consulting with regard to the plan— My brother and Mr Miller came up while we were there Mr Beale and Mr Miller, wished me to alter the direction of the boundary Fence, as it stands, and give a larger front upon the road; but I did not think it would be an improvement upon the appearance of the lot or of the School-house. We got home about 3 O’clock. After dinner, Mrs Smith, Mrs Hall, Mrs Pickman, and Mr Thomas Smith paid us a short visit from Boston. Though much fatigued with my Morning’s excursion, I wrote, two or three hours of the Evening— I read this Morning the first Chapter of the first Book of Grahame’s History. His characters of Raleigh and of John Smith, are lively spirited, and just— His contempt of James the first, corrosive. His chastisements of Dr. Robertson and Chalmers severe and richly merited. I read also a few pages of the Life of Arthur Lee, and 3 Numbers of Dr Waterhouse’s Independent whig.
21. IV:30. Saturday.

Deacon Adams, called immediately after dinner, and with him I examined all the old titles of my father’s Estate in Quincy, comparing them with the plans recently taken by Mr Humphrey— My first object in this examination was to ascertain how it happened that the Penn’s Valley farm, upon Mr Humphrey’s Survey falls so much short of the quantity assigned to it in my fathers deed of 6 August 1803. I ascertained this error, which is chiefly if not all in the Deed— Before this Estate was conveyed to me, it was appraised at my fathers request, by my Uncle Peter B. Adams, John Hall and James Brackett; and they made the mistake— They estimated the paternal homestead then tenanted by John Briesler at fifty Acres, whereas it was only 35. and the place purchased of Vesey at 48. which was only 46. They thus made 108 Acres where there were only 91—but the 7 Acres purchased of Moses and Huldah Babcock still remain unaccounted for. I rectified in this examination also
some of my own errors with regard to the location of lands in some of the old Deeds. In a single instance, that of the Town River Saltmarsh, the Survey gives more land than the Deeds. In all the others there is a deduction— The loss on the mass of Surveys of my fathers property and mine is little less than 40 Acres— The Deacon was here till after dark; and I read over to him the bounds of all the Deeds, which I did not already know; and he made most of them known to me— After he was gone I went with W. C. Greenleaf to Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s— I delivered to him my Letter to the Supervisors of the Temple and School fund, inviting them to call a meeting of the Ministers, Magistrates, Lawyers and Physicians inhabiting in the Town of Quincy, to determine what Arts and Sciences, and what languages besides the Greek and Latin shall be taught at the proposed School— This must be decided before the School-house can be built and even before the School can be established— I had also some conversation with Mr Greenleaf upon the plan for laying out the School-house Square in house-Lots— A project entirely my own, and for the event of which I have much solicitude— I executed and acknowledged before Mr Greenleaf as a Justice of Peace, a Mortgage of two houses in Boston, as a substitute for that of the Penn’s Valley farm; to my father’s Executors— Read this Morning the Second Chapter of the first Book of Grahame’s History; which carries the History of Virginia to the Restoration of Charles the second— The Importation of purchaseable wives—the Indian Massacre; and the continual alternation of good and bad governors, constitute the Interest of this period— The Cavalier Colony adhered to the Stuarts, and were rewarded for it with a double share of oppression.
22. V. Sunday.

Heard Mr Dean of Scituate—from 2. Kings 22.11. “And it came to pass when the king had heard the words of the book of the Law, that he rent his clothes.”— He read the whole chapter, and the Sermon was an exposition of the whole transaction recorded in it; the discovery of the Book of the Law by Hilkiah the High Priest in the reign of Josiah— Upon this very remarkable part of the old Testament I had about a month since a Conversation with Mr Brooks of Hingham, and asked him a number of Questions which he was not then prepared to answer— When Miss Thaxter was here she renewed the subject; and Mr Dean’s Sermon answered most of the questions that I had put to Mr Brooks— Mr Dean dined with us; and my nephew John Quincy. Mr Dean’s afternoon Sermon was from Luke 19.1–10 The story of Zaccheus— After this Service, I attended the funeral of Ann Adams, eldest daughter of my late Cousin Boylston Adams about 25 years old. She died of a lingering consumption— The funeral prayer was made by Mr Dean. There are yet three daughters of my Cousin Boylston, but no male descendant from my uncle Peter of the name of Adams. This is the fourth funeral from that house since I came here last June— Peter Turner’s two Children, Boylston himself and now his daughter. I had scarcely ever seen this young woman and I cannot commit to writing the thoughts which oppressed me while I followed her to the grave— The Lesson of the Scripture is in no case to despair of the Mercy of God— Let me not abandon my faith. I read this morning the third Chapter of Grahame’s first Book, which completes the History of the Colony of Virginia to the end of the seventeenth Century— New England is the favourite Colony of Mr Grahame, and the favorite Colony she will be of every honest, philosophical and religious enquirer after Truth, who shall search the fountains of American History— There was no magnanimous or consciencious purpose in the Settlement of Virginia— No spirit of Freedom. It was all mere adventurous speculation— John Smith’s adventures and Bacon’s Rebellion, contain all the
interesting part of the History of Virginia for the first Century. I read also this Evening two Sermons of Barrow upon Quietness and doing our own business— The doctrinal morality of these discourses is more obsolete than their language. There is a passage in the first of these Sermons in which he considers all discussion upon public affairs or public men an injurious and pragmatical in private individuals; and he quotes with approbation the apostrophe of Marcus Terentius to Tiberius, in Tacitus— To thee the Gods have given the Supreme authority— To us is left the glory of obsequiousness “obsequia Gloria”— This Doctor Barrow thinks is all that Subjects can claim or ought to desire— The Servility of this passage would not be endured in the present age.
23. V:15. Monday.

The morning was so dark, that I could neither write by daylight, two hours after the Sun had risen— I had promised Mr Curtis to meet him in Boston this morning; but after a heavy thunder shower while we were at breakfast the rain continued all the morning so that I concluded not to leave the house— I answered Mr Brooks’s invitation to pass Thanksgiving day with him at Medford by accepting it, and wrote to Charles. After dinner Deacon Spear and his brother William came, and the Deacon paid me what he had received for the standing wood sold last week on the Railway ledge lot—42 lots, about 1/5 of an Acre to a lot sold at different prices from 2:50 to 20 dollars a lot— The whole sold for 389 dollars 20 Cents, from which he deducts ten per Cent for his fees of selling the wood and collecting the money— One per Cent for the tax— Of the balance he paid me more than one third in cash, and gave me his note payable on the first of May for the remainder— I paid the Bill of William Spear who charged me 9 1/2 days Surveying for himself and Elijah Baxter each at 1 1/2 dollar a day— Exorbitant charges which I could not reasonably contest, as I had neglected to make my bargain before hand— I spoke to Deacon Spear of advertising my Penn’s Valley farm, for a lease; but he thought it would be best to wait until the Month of March— As the rain held up after dinner I walked to my brother’s— His daughter Elizabeth is confined to her chamber threatened with a pulmonary fever. My brother and Edward Miller came back with me, and they attended a Meeting of the Supervisors, at G. W. Beale’s— I received a Note from my Son Charles, advising me that the Susan and Phoebe had arrived at Boston, and was at the Head of the Long wharf— I sent immediately for Mr Hubbard the Sexton, and engaged him to go into Boston early to-morrow Morning; and to give me immediate notice when he returns— I read little this Evening. In the morning I had read the third Book of Grahame’s History consisting of one Chapter and containing the History of the Settlement of Maryland. He is very favourable to the first and second Lord’s Baltimore, and thinks the founder of the Colony of Maryland more entitled to the reputation of setting the first example of Toleration than William Penn— He accounts well for the singular fact, that the Courtier quaker founder of a principality should have taken from a Roman Catholic Nobleman, the praise of toleration, and from the democratic puritans of New-England that of humane and honest dealings with the Indians.
24. V. Tuesday.

I called this morning at Mr Whitney’s, and informed him of the arrival of the vessel with the remains of my deceased Son, and repeated the request that he would make a short prayer at their re-interment, with which he readily complied— About half past one Mr Hubbard returned from Boston: I went to the burying yard with W. C. Greenleaf; and after a short and impressive prayer by Mr Whitney, the case containing the Coffin was deposited in the family Tomb— May a blessed and merciful God, accept the tribute of gratitude that I have been permitted to perform this last act of duty to the earthly ruins of my child! May I cherish the hope that this afflictive dispensation comes not as the first stroke of the destroying Angel, but as the discipline of a chastising hand? In this Journal was recorded on the 12th of April 1801. the birth of this my first born Son. Desired How long, how anxiously! granted to fervent prayers after frequent disappointments. With what earnestness of hope: with what anguish of fear have we followed the course of his short career? How small a portion of his life was passed under the paternal roof! With what exquisite delight I have hailed the gleams of prosperous fortune, which so rarely illumined his path—and how have I grieved in Spirit at the afflictions with which it was so thickly beset— His heart so full of the kindliest affections! His Spirit glowing with the most exalted purity— A Soul abstracted from the business of earthly concerns, that it could not endure the contemplation of its own infirmities. Heavenly father let it have mercy before thee; and in the day of retribution let not my errors be visited upon my child!
25. IV. Wednesday. Fahrenheit 20. Sun rose at

I rode to Boston with John Thomas and William Dutton who has lived with me now since the first of October At the entrance upon the Neck I left my Carriage and walked to Charles’s Office, where I found Mr Nathl. Curtis— We executed a Deed of Land, according to the some upon which we had finally agreed, and also an assignment to Salem Towne of all the demands and Estate of Ward N. Boylston at Mount Desert and our part of the Indenture by which he is to pay one thousand dollars for them; and 200 dollars more in the Event of his recovering more than 1500 dollars. I sent to enquire of Coll. Quincy if his father was in Town— The Coll. came and said his father was not in town this day but would be on Friday Morning. I met in Court Street Isaac P. Davis who has lately returned from Washington. He asked me to sit to Miss Stuart who has painted a copy of Stuart’s last Portrait of me; which I promised to do on Friday. He also mentioned the old Portrait of my Ancestor Coll. John Quincy as a Child, which Stuart took to repair; which he kept until his death without repairing—which then fell into the hands of a man named Jones, and which Davis finally rescued from a Sheriff’s Sale— He said also that he had seen Sully in Philadelphia, who had as yet only a miniature sketch of his finishing part of Stuart’s last Portrait of me—and he thought I should do well in going through Philadelphia to ask judge Hopkinson to see to Sully’s finishing the work— I dined with my Son Charles and expected to have taken him and his wife with me this Evening to Medford, but they had engaged company at home. Dutton came to me, and said that the Steam-boat for Portland would go to-morrow; and he wished not to lose the opportunity to go home— He asked therefore for his discharge; which I gave him, and paid him his discharge— I transferred to my Son Charles my
my share in the Athenaeum lately recovered N. 255. in the afternoon. I came out to Mr P. C. Brooks’s at Medford. Mr Brooks was out but got home a few minutes after I arrived— Mrs Edward Everett and her three daughters Ann Gorham, Charlotte and Grace Webster, are here— Mr Everett himself went last Monday for Washington. Mrs Brooks remains much in the same state of health as when I was here last.
26. VI. Thursday. Thanksgiving day.

I rose at Six—lighted my candle with my flint, steel and match which I had brought; and then made my fire— Read three Chapters of the Book of Job, and wrote till I was called to breakfast. I went with Mr Brooks to Meeting and heard Mr. Stetson, from 1. John 4.19. “For we love him, because he first loved us.”—upon the love of God. A very ingenious and rational Discourse; with some passages of good writing. Mr Stetson acknowledged the impossibility of our forming any definite conceptions of the Nature of God; and discriminated well between the ideas annexed to the term love as applied to our fellow Creatures and to God— In the text the Love of God, is resolved into Gratitude; but who shall mark the difference between the term love when applied to the action of God’s benevolence to man and the return of man’s worship to God— What means the word Love as applied from God to man— God created man— Is creation an Act of love— God created the world and every animated being in it— The beasts of the forest, the fishes of the Sea, the fowls of the Air and the Cattle upon a thousand hills. Love is therefore not manifested in the act of Creation. The Love of God to man, was manifested in the endowments bestowed upon man, especially in that of an immortal Soul— The benevolence of God to man is manifested by all the enjoyments of his existence by all the powers that he exercises, by all the hopes of immortality which he is permitted to conceive and entertain— For all this gratitude is doubtless due from man; and gratitude is a sentiment of the heart— But the love of man can make no return of beneficence to God— It can be manifested only in worship, in obedience to his will, and in beneficence to our fellow creatures— Man can make no return of good to God— He can neither add to nor deduct from his blessedness; but gratitude for benefits received is conformable to the nature of man, and is necessary to him for the enjoyment of them— Gratitude to God is therefore one of the blessings conferred by God upon man; and the Love of God, is no other than Self-love. The collection of Hymns used here has been collected by a man at Cambridge named Dabney, and is apparently inferior to that of Dr. Belknap. The compilation of Psalms and Hymns has become a Bookseller’s job, and the consequence is that they become Sectarian books, and almost every Society has a different one— The Hymn How beauteous are their feet is omitted from this collection— I question whether in the whole collection there is one equal to it— Mr Brooks’s Son Edward and his wife, Mr Frothingham and his wife, and my Son Charles and his wife came and dined with their Parents of this family— I asked Mr Frothingham if he would give us a century Sermon next Summer; he answered dubiously. Charles and his wife stay here to night.
27. V. Friday.— Snow— Returned to Quincy.

On rising this morning I found the ground covered with Snow which had fallen in the Night— I read and wrote as usual three hours till breakfast time, having come prepared for that purpose. After breakfast Charles’s wife came into Boston with me, and Charles with Mr Brooks— Coll. Quincy called at Charles’s Office with a note from his father advising that he could not come to Boston—inviting me to dine with him at Cambridge which I could not without inconvenience, and sending back the two Deeds I had sent him with some remarks. I went to the Branch Bank, and made my arrangements preparatory to my departure for Washington— Having applied to the purchase on my own account of three Gallery pews in the Meeting House at Quincy the sum of 168 dollars which I received for two years Interest upon the Note for 1600 dollars of the Parish Treasurer to the Executors of my father; I now allowed interest upon it from the 5th. of October When I received it to this day 1:50. and deposited 169:50 to the credit of the Executors— I then by a transfer of 600 dollars from the credit of the Executors, to that of my private account, borrowed that sum for which I left with my Son Charles a Note upon interest for 600 dollars to be delivered to my Co-executor Mr Quincy—and I then drew by a Check 400 dollars from my private credit, to pay off my outstanding Bills and debts here, and the expenses of my Journey to Washington— Thence I called at Mr Isaac P Davis’s and saw Mrs Davis— Then at Mrs Stuarts the widow of the Painter and sat about half an hour to Miss Stuart his daughter who has made a copy of the head taken of me by her father in 1825. She merely chalked out my dress intending to finish it as a work of her own. I came home to dine at Quincy; and immediately after dinner attended a meeting of the Ministers, Magistrates, Lawyers and Physicians of the Town, at French’s Tavern, to determine upon the studies, additional to the Greek and Latin Languages, to be pursued at the Classical School proposed in my father’s donations to the Town— There were present Thomas Greenleaf my brother, Edward Miller and G. W. Beale, Supervisors, and all but Mr Beale, Magistrates—Noah Curtis, Lemuel Brackett and John Whitney Magistrates, Peter Whitney, the Minister, Mr Gourgas a Lawyer, and Doctor Woodward a Physician— The only persons of the defined denominations, absent were Deacon Spear a Magistrate, and Mr Douglas the occasional minister of the Episcopal Church— My Letter to the Supervisors requesting the call of this Meeting was read, and after some discussion, a unanimous vote was passed, advising that the additional studies should be those required for admission at any of our Universities; no pupil to be admitted but after an examination in reading, writing and arithmetic through the double rule of three as taught in the common Schools— After I returned home Alpheus, and Lemuel Spear were here, and we executed a renewal of the lease to them of the Mount Wollaston Farm, for two years from 1 April 1831. when their present lease would expire.
28. V:30. Saturday.

Harvey Field was here, and I paid him my tax-bill; about which my enquiries have not very satisfactorily terminated— I have settled also a Bill of Mr Mills the Painter and Glazier— I sent John Thomas with the Carriage in to Boston, and my Son Charles and his wife came out before dinner— I had company to dine Thomas Greenleaf, my brother, George W. Beale, and Edward Miller, the Supervisors of the Temple and School-fund— Peter Whitney, Mr Douglas, John Marston, Daniel Greenleaf and William Smith—and Mr Gourgas—W. C. Greenleaf, Charles and his wife, and Mary Foster,
with Louisa Smith, and myself 16 at Table— The company left us early in the Evening— My regular occupations are still interrupted, but I resumed this morning the reading of Grahame’s History, and went through the first Chapter of the fifth Book being the History of the Settlement of New-York— On Tuesday and Wednesday Morning’s I read the two Chapters of the fourth Book being the History of North and South-Carolina, which is chiefly remarkable, as the experimental trial of the philosophical Constitution of John Locke, and its signal failure—a Utopia realized. Mr Grahame stigmatizes with great severity the character of the Earl of Shaftesbury, and considers the reputation of Locke as somewhat tarnished by his connection with so vile a personage— He was grandfather to the author of the Characteristicks.
29. V. Sunday.

Foul and Stormy day. Heard Mr Nicholas Bowes Whitney; this morning from Matthew 25.19. “After a long time the lord of those servants cometh, and reckoneth with them,” and in the afternoon from Proverbs 22.2. “The rich and poor meet together: The Lord is the maker of them all.” I had heard a Sermon from this text on the 21st. of June last from Mr Young. Mr Whitney dined with us— And Mr Degrand, who came out from Boston, and gave us the unwelcome intelligence that Mr James H. Foster’s warehouse at the corner of Summer Street was this morning about four O’Clock consumed to ashes by fire. He said it was rumoured the loss of goods was to the amount of 20000 dollars, and that he had only 8000 dollars insured— After the afternoon Service, Degrand had a long conversation with me upon politicks, and chiefly upon the question of whether it would be advisable to set up immediately Mr Clay as an opposition candidate for the Presidency— I repeated what I had said heretofore— That it would be well to wait, and see if Mr Clay, would be brought forward by his own State— I did not think he would; believing that Thomas H. Benton, had supplanted him in the popular favour of the West— Degrand thought that the Legislature of Massachusetts would nominate Clay, if I should recommend him. I told Degrand that I perceived no necessity for my interfering with the election— The present prospect is that Jackson will be re-elected without opposition, as long as he lives— As to his successor, if Van Buren, Calhoun, and Benton should be the candidates, they are all political profligates; the principles of Benton being those of a highway robber—Van Buren’s those of a dirty intriguer, and Calhoun’s mere prostitution to popularity. To either of those men, it was desirable that New-England should never degrade herself by giving support. Mr Clay is far above them all in character, but if he should ever recover popular favour, sufficient to bring him forward as a Candidate it must be by some discontent raised by the mismanagement of this administration— This cannot happen for some time, and if it should happen, Mr Clay’s popularity must first disclose itself in the West— It will be time enough for New-England then to move. I thought it probable however that the approaching Session of Congress would give some new direction to parties, and that the Members in that Body from New-England, would be solicited to take their sides. At present it was impossible to foresee what would be the strife of party or who would be the combatants.
30. V. Monday.

I commence my preparations for my departure for Washington, with mortification at the thought how little I have done in the half year that I have been here— Should it please Heaven to take me away before I can return here, my affairs would be left in nearly as much disorder as they would have been six Months back; and amidst the blessings yet left me, the harrow is upon my Soul for the calamity that cannot be repaired— Enough— My Son Charles with his wife returned this Morning— May the blessing of God be with them! My brother was here; and gave me an abstract of his account, leaving a balance of 950:35 due to me, for which he promised to give me his note— He spoke of placing his Son John Quincy at the Exeter Academy and I promised to pay the expense of his board— I dined with Louisa Smith, Mary Foster and W. C. Greenleaf at Mr John Greenleaf’s. Mr and Mrs Daniel Greenleaf were there— After dinner I called upon Mr Samuel Curtis, but he was not at home. I saw however his father, and spoke to him of an arrangement by which I may lease in the Spring the house in which S. Curtis lives, and from which he proposes to go out the first of September next— As there will be no prospect of leasing the house at that Season, I wished to advertise it in the Spring, in such manner that Curtis might remain in the house till he will be ready to go into the one that he proposes to build— Peter Turner and Josiah Adams junr were here this Evening with their Accounts which I settled— I wrote to my wife to inform her of my intention to depart hence the day after to-morrow, and was occupied till Midnight.

Day. I continue to rise usually between 4. and 6. O’Clock; average about 5. But after reading 3 Chapters of the Bible, the coldness of the Season has compelled me to substitute reading instead of writing until breakfast. I have the last fortnight read a chapter of Grahame’s History every Morning. We now breakfast between 8 and 9. We dine at two— Have tea at six or seven—and between nine and ten I retire to bed. The unpacking of my library received from Boston has been completed; but I have been obliged to put them up as they came from the boxes; they are in great disorder and no catalogue of them has been made— The details of the household absorb no small portion of my time— Many of my books entice away here and there an occasional hour— The plans of my Surveys— The Title Deeds of my father’s Estates— The disposal of my farms and the Administration of my father’s, W. N. Boylston’s and T. Boylston’s Estates, with transient visitors and occasional interruptions have brought me to the time of my necessary departure for Washington.— If my life and health are spared; I pray that I may be enabled to give a better account of the next Season, here.
